text:
_*A very open-ended question but I'd appreciate your answers:*_

How do you analyze a company's content marketing strategy?

elements.text: A very open-ended question but I'd appreciate your answers:
How do you analyze a company's content marketing strategy?

text:
Review:
• Channels they're on
• Content types they put out
• Content cadence/frequency
• Content partnerships (if any)
• SEO rankings for their keywords
I'm sure there's more, these are just off the top of my head.

text:
Hey there! Doing some research on how top performing marketers and growth folks make time to learn a new skill or sharpen the saw.

Do you watch Youtube videos every Monday for an hour? Spend Thursday’s going for a walk listening to an audiobook?  Go through your Instapaper / Readwise daily?

For in the weeds content folks especially, it can be challenging to set aside time to learn. I’m curious to know how ya’ll handle it.

elements.text:

Do you watch Youtube videos every Monday for an hour? Spend Thursday’s going for a walk listening to an audiobook?  Go through your Instapaper / Readwise daily?

For in the weeds content folks especially, it can be challenging to set aside time to learn. I’m curious to know how ya’ll handle it.

text: Like instead of just spending so much time on effort on producing content. Packaging that knowledge into something where clients can set up their own content strategy themselves, know how to hire writers, Ideate, formulate briefs, etc. I work with a lot of startups that have these challenges but I don’t have time to like, write for them all. I dunno does that make sense? Kind of spit balling here lol

text:
I've a simple process for this:

1) I decide what to learn fast and go as specific as possible.

2) I find a solid guide (recommended is preferable) on that topic. I complete it in one sitting.

3) I listen to a couple of podcast episodes (again research is key) to strengthen my knowledge. 

It works well for me; might not be the same for everyone else.

text:
I'm working  with a fast-growing proptech producing a lot of content (landing pages, emails, decks, etc.) to support a product launch. As we prepare the collateral to support the launch, we get word that .5% needs to become 0.5% or that when could once say "we'll close in as few as 14 days" we now have to say "we can provide a quick close." How do you all handle updating tiny but important content snippets like this across an enterprise. I'm struggling. We've got so much content in so many different places.

In general we need to focus more on content ops (formalize requests of the content marketing team, limit feedback to a narrower window of time, create RACI charts for content projects, etc.) So, if you have any books, articles, software or other resources to recommend to get us started, please share. TIA.

elements.text:

As we prepare the collateral to support the launch, we get word that .5% needs to become 0.5% or that when could once say "we'll close in as few as 14 days" we now have to say "we can provide a quick close." How do you all handle updating tiny but important content snippets like this across an enterprise. I'm struggling. We've got so much content in so many different places.

In general we need to focus more on content ops (formalize requests of the content marketing team, limit feedback to a narrower window of time, create RACI charts for content projects, etc.) So, if you have any books, articles, software or other resources to recommend to get us started, please share. TIA.

text:
In my last job ( a content marketing agency) we were encouraged to block our calendars each week as the learning day. This day was when you immerse yourself to just "learn" —no questions asked. You could either spend time on YouTube, take a certification or do something else. Of course it came with some level of accountability in the form of presenting your learnings to the team. This way we all learnt.

I have tried to bring a toned-down version of it to my new role too. I consciously block time ( 2 hrs each week on Tuesday) to watch that Youtube video, read that article, or just block sometime with for a topic based coffee chat with someone in the industry.

I have tried to bring a toned-down version of it to my new role too. I consciously block time ( 2 hrs each week on Tuesday) to watch that Youtube video, read that article, or just block sometime with for a topic based coffee chat with someone in the industry.

text:
Gather Content: <https://gathercontent.com/>

It’s like content version control.

Note, I haven’t used this in depth. But I was researching software to help with situations like the ones you described. Where one seemingly small change turns into a manual review of many documents, CTRL+Fing our way through it, praying we didn’t miss anything.

Edit: Now I’m itching to sign up and use this for real.

text: I love how Target turned a crappy experience (they cancelled my order with very little notice) into a positive experience (a not-negligible amount of store credit). I hardly even remembered this happened until you asked for examples.

elements.text: I love how Target turned a crappy experience (they cancelled my order with very little notice) into a positive experience (a not-negligible amount of store credit). I hardly even remembered this happened until you asked for examples.

text: From a copy standpoint, I love that the first two points of information you get are "Sorry" and "We're sending you a gift"... made it very clear what was happening, so it was hard to get too upset.

elements.text: From a copy standpoint, I love that the first two points of information you get are "Sorry" and "We're sending you a gift"... made it very clear what was happening, so it was hard to get too upset.
